author: paul bennett
text: william james was a smart philosopher who cleaved reality into two realms: those things we perceive - percepts - and those we think about - concepts. the one sticking point in james's thinking was: how does perception take place? how do percepts become concepts? today, we might offer "information" as the bridge - the little bits of stuff that enter our minds from the outside world and form the basis of our thinking. but what, james might retort, is information? surely the ubiquity of the word has dissolved its resonance. albert borgmann, a philosophy professor at the university of montana, has offered a stunningly clear definition of information in holding on to reality: the nature of information at the turn of the millennium. borgmann describes three kinds of reality: natural, cultural, and technological. natural kinds of information - our oldest type of data, such as tracks in snow or cairns formed in a landscape - are inextricably tied to the real world; they are clues that most directly tell us something about something. borgmann then spins us forward a few hundred years to when human civilization begins to vigorously replace natural information with cultural information, such as books, music, and laws. this data is devised as a tool to assist our dealings with the world. easy enough.the third wave in borgmann's description is the evolution of information into a technological form (digital may be more appropriate). here information becomes its own reality. he uses several vivid examples, the best of which is the difference between viewing the objets d'art in london's national gallery online or in person. what is the actual, physical context of each experience? writes borgmann: "virtual reality, however expansive, is finally bounded and connects itself to nothing, while the actual gallery borders on trafalgar square adjoining in turn st. martin's church and neighboring charing cross and so on in the inexhaustible texture of streets and focal points that is london." for technological boosters and sci-fi writers he leaves room for little argument, unless one wants to pose the now vogue objection: i guess it depends on what you mean by nothing.holding on to reality: the nature of information at the turn of the millennium by albert borgmann: $22. university of chicago press: +1 (773) 702 7700, www.press.uchicago.edu.street credbrother's keepercryptic adventureshave it your wayshout it outkiller opbatman's second lifereality checkrobo scopemusicjust outta betareadmepersonalized checkingdeep knowledge'phone of silencewatts for dinnerthe public face of linuxcontributors
